title: Riot, please make Rek'Sai's lore first person.
body: Currently, she has no quotes whatsoever (unlike Gnar who just isn't speaking our language). I think her not being able to speak is fine, but her problem currently is that because she is so in-human in both appearance and personality, she feels more like a glorified jungle monster rather than a champion. Because of this, I think her lore really need to be in first person (just like Vel'Koz and Sion). If you do the same to her as you did to Gnar's and Kalista's lores, she won't be anything else than mindless beast (which is *not* what voidborn are meant to be btw.) We need to get a look into her head to see that there's more to her than "land shark from the void that eat travelers".

OP wants to put her in first person.
Putting her in first person means putting her thoughts in a way humans can understand.
Such an action inherently means humanizing her, or turning her into less of a monster.

Disagree.

*Hunger.*

*Wait for pray.*

*Feel heat on sand. Not like home. Not like dark.*

*Sense tremor. Burrow. Attack from beneath.*

*Prey moves fast. Can feel fear. Hunger overtakes.*

*Dig.*

*Breach.*

*Kill.*

*Consume.*

You get the idea. My point is, "dehumanizing" does not necessitate "lacking understandable thoughts". Doesn't mean she will or won't have a first person narrative or that it would be comprehendable if she did, merely that monster =/= non-comprehendable.

My point is that even though she's not human and can't speak, it doesn't mean she's not intelligent. Most voidborn seem to be (at least Vel'Koz and Cho'Gath are said to be very intelligent). There's currently nothing about her that indicates she's intelligent though, she just seems like a mindless beast. By making her lore first-person, Riot can change this. She doesn't have to react to things or think like a human would (I'd rather have her not), but at least show that she actually has an understanding of what's happening around her, rather than reacting 100% on instinct.
But what's wrong with a monster champion that reacts purely on instinct? Frankly, I don't feel that Morde or Heca or Kalista have anymore depth by speaking English than Rek'Sai does.

I don't think it's wrong for a monster character, but when it's a *champion* I think it need some kind of intelligence. I know the league is not a thing anymore, but like I said before: A monster champion that is just a mindless beast feels more like a playable jungle monster rather than a champion.

A monster doesn't need to be mindless to be running around and wreacking havoc. Just look at Cho'Gath. He doesn't have a new lore yet, but just looking at his new splash art tells me he'll be doing a lot of Kaiju stuff. 

In a character driven story where all playable characters are meant to be sort of main characters (although some obviously get more attention than others), a mindless beast (in my opinion) just doesn't work. It will never be able to interact with other characters in any ways except "run away from or fight against". This might be cool once or twice (at most), but after that this same concept just gets boring. After that, we've got a main character that can't be put in any new stories because it would just make them feel repetitive. 

The story-role of a mindless beast can be filled with a lot of other things anyways, like Baron. We don't need a champion to do this.

Not sure if first person would be a good idea, but I agree that she needs more depth.

Yes, Gj Riot for releasing a nonpandering female monster champ, but at the same time it would be incredibly boring for her to simply be a monster based on instinct.

IMO, the overall plot increases in depth when the "monsters" have some explanation.  For example:  

- The rachni from mass effect are initially perceived as mindless monsters, but then you learn that they are actually very intelligent sentient creatures who communicate by songs.

- The darkspawn from Dragon Age are initially presented as unknown mindless plagues, but their origin turns out to be far more messed up.  Throw in the awakening DLC plot in there for and extra good story time.

- The zerg overmind is/was a very charismatic personality; without it, the race would simply not be as interesting

- The witches in the Madoka anime

- Song of Saya visual novel


Of course, it depends on the context.  In some cases, details can ruin the experience (Reapers explanation in ME3)



Rek'Sai is a nonspeaking monster champ placed into a setting that currently doesn't exist because Riot deleted the old lore and didn't make the new one yet.  There is no framework or context, no speech, no dialogue, NOTHING.  Broodmother in Dota2 has a voice, and it's cool; she doesn't lose her monster card just because she's voiced.  Giving Rek'Sai minor personification or some context isn't going to diminish her status as a monster, and more than likely may strengthen it.
I was never a  fan of the first-person lore entries, but given Rek'Sai's disappointing VO, I could go for one. At the very least we'd have SOME kind of idea as to who she is and what drives her.

I think her lore should be third-person, probably like Gnar's; IMO this preserves the "other" feeling that Void champions give off (although TBF Vel'Koz's lore does not do this). That said, she needs lines.

To me it doesn't make sense that we wouldn't be able to understand her (or Gnar). Languages in fiction get translated constantly, it's not really something to complain about. We as summoners can understand every champion except Gnar and Rek. Why? Why are they much more 'alien' than others? Surely Taric, Kayle, Morgana, pre-retcon Nasus and Renekton, Malphite, Olaf, Anivia, Nidalee, Trundle, Rammus (Okay), Fizz, Nami and any other champions from far off lands and such would not speak recognizable Runeterrestrial languages, and yet we understand them just fine. The logic doesn't add up to Gnar and Rek being unintelligible. 

Having her lore from her perspective would be far superior than any third person story in my opinion. Sure third person is unique, but it doesn't really make up for the loss of her own voice. Show, don't tell.
I hope her lore is written from Kha's perspective so she remains a monster but we get more direct information about her and her species.
